body.stage: Scene--Athens: before the houses of PERIPHANES, APÆCIDES, and CHÆRIBULUS.

div2.head: THE SUBJECT.
div2.p: The plot of this Play is of an involved nature. Periphanes, an aged Athenian, has a son, born in wedlock, named Stratippocles. By Philippa, a woman of Epidaurus, whom he has formerly seduced, he has had a daughter, named Telestis who has been residing with her mother at Thebes. A war arising between the Athenians and Thebans, Stratippocles, on setting out for the army, commissions Epidicus, his father's servant, to purchase for him Acropolistis, a music-girl, of whom lie is enamoured. Epidicns, on this, persuades Periphanes that this girl is really his daughter by Philippa, whom he has not seen for many years, and that she has been taken captive at Thebes, and brought to Athens. On this the old man gives Epidicus the requisite sum, and she is brought home and introduced to him as his daughter Telestis. In the meantime, Stratippocles meets with another damsel who has been taken captive, and agrees with a Banker to borrow forty mince, for the purpose of purchasing her. He returns to Athens, and resolves not to meet his father until he has paid the money to the Banker and gained possession of the damsel, and Epidicus is threatened by him with a severe punishment, if he does not manage to raise the sum required. On this he accosts his aged master, and tells him that he must find a wife for his son, who is about to purchase a singing-girl of the name of Acropolistis. The old man is persuaded to give a sum of money to Epidicus for the purpose of buying Acropolistis, that she may be kept out of the way of his son. On receiving the money, Epidicus hands it over to Stratippocles, to be paid to the Banker. The old gentleman having that morning ordered a singing-girl to be hired to perform at a sacrifice at his house, she is brought to him as Acropolistis, having been instructed how to play her part. A Captain, who admires Acropolistis, having heard that Periphanes has purchased her, applies to him, and offers to give him a profit of ten minæ if he will transfer her to him. Periphanes, thereupon, brings to him the music-girl who is assuming that character (while the real Acropolistis is taken for his daughter), on which the Captain discovers the deception, and Periphanes finds out that the girl is already free, and has been only brought to his house to perform at the sacrifice. At this conjuncture Philippa arrives, having heard that her daughter has been brought to Athens. Periphanes meets her, and assures her that her daughter is safe at his house. On this, Philippa is introduced to Acropolistis, and declares that she is not her daughter, and that Periphanes has been imposed upon. On being questioned,Acropolistis confesses that she has only called Periphanes her father because lie has called her his daughter. Epidicus, on being discovered to be guilty of this second fraud upon his master, is greatly alarmed; but just then he perceives the Banker, who has come for the money, leading the Theban captive. He immediately recognizes her as Telestis, the real daughter of Periphanes and Philippa, Stratippocles, somewhat to his sorrow, is informed that the captive is his half-sister, and therefore, most probably, consoles himself with Acropolistis. For making this discovery, Epidicus is not only pardoned by Periphanes, but receives his freedom.

div2.head: THE ACROSTIC ARGUMENT.[Supposed to have been written by Priscian the Grammarian.]
div2.p: An old gentleman, thinking her his daughter, purchases (Emit) a music-girl, by the advice (Persuasu) of his servant, who, a second time (Iterum), substitutes for him, in place of his son's mistress, another one hired; he gives (Dat) to his master's son the money; with it the young man, not knowing it (Imprudens), purchases his sister. Soon afterwards, by the aid of a woman whom he has seduced, and of a Captain, the old man understands (Cognoscit) that he has been imposed upon, as (Ut) the one is in search of his mistress, the other of her daughter. But (Sed) on finding his daughter, he gives his servant his liberty.

div1.stage: Enter THESPRIO, followed by EPIDICUS.Translator's subtitle The Fortunate Discovery: Plautus calls this Play by the name of Epidicus, from the slave, who is the principal actor in it. It will be seen that a fortunate discovery really does take place in the Fifth Act, where Periphanes not only finds his long-lost daughter, but Stratippocles is prevented from unknowingly being guilty of incest. That Plautus thought very highly of this Play, is evident from what is said in the Bacchides, l. 215, where Chrysalus is introduced as saying that he "loves the Epidicus as well as his own self."

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: pulling THESPRIO by the cloak. Harkye! young man.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Who pulls me by the cloak, when thus in haste?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: An intimate.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: I confess it; for with your annoyance you are too intimate.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: But do look back, Thesprio!

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: looking round. What? Is it Epidicus that I see?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Why surely you've the use of your eyes.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Greetings to you.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: May the Gods grant what you desire. I'm glad that you've got here safe.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: What besides?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: According to the usage, a dinner shall be given youA dinner shall be given you: The "cœna viatica," or "welcome entertainment," has been mentioned in the Notes to the Bacchides, Act I., So. 2..

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: That I'll accept it, if you offer it.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: How are you? Fare you as you could wish?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: The proof's before you.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I understand. Eyeing him from top to toe. Marvellous! You seem quite plump and hearty.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: pointing to his left hand. Thanks to this.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Which, indeed, you ought to have parted withTo have parted with: The thieves of antiquity are said to have used the left hand for the purposes of their nefarious calling. The cutting off of the hand was a common punishment. long ago.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: I'm less of a pilferer now than formerly.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: I rob above-boardI rob above- board: It has been suggested that this is an imitation of a passage in Aristophanes, Act II., Sc. 3, where Blepsidemus says, "ou) keklofa/s a)/ll' h(/rpakas." "You have not pilfered, but plundered." The thought, however, is quite natural, without resorting to a previous author for it..

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: May the immortal Gods confound you, with what huge strides you do walk! for when I caught sight of you at the harbour, I began to run at a rapid pace; I was hardly able to overtake you just now.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: You are a town wit.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I know that you, on the other hand, are a military gentleman.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Speak out as boldly as you please.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: How say you? Have you been well all along?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: In a varied way.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Those who are well in a varied wayIn a varied way: He puns upon the different meanings of the word "varie;" and alludes to the checquered or striped state of the slave's back after whipping. By "varie," Thesprio simply means, "sometimes well, and sometimes ill.", a race of men of the goat kind or of the panther kind, don't please me.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: What do you wish me to tell you but that which is fact?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: To answer to these things fairly; how's our master's son? Is he well?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Stout as a boxer and an athlete.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: You've brought me joyous tidings on your arrival. But where is he?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: I came here together with him.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Where is he then? Unless, perchance, you've brought him in your wallet, or, perhaps, in your knapsack.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: May the Gods confound you!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I want to make enquiries of you. Lend me your attention; attention shall be lent you in return.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: You say what's lawWhat's law: The words "operam da" and "operam dabo," used by Epidicus, were terms used in the Roman courts of law: therefore Thesprio says, "jus dicis," meaning, "you talk like a judge.".

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: It becomes me to do so.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: But why now are you acting the Prætor over us?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What other person in Athens will you say is more deserving of it than I?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: But still, Epidicus, one thing is wanting for your Prætorship.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What, pray?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: You shall know; two lictorsTwo lictors: The Prætors were attended by lictors As one part of their duty was to scourge refractory slaves, Thesprio means to joke Epidicus, by telling him that he requires the lictors -- not to do him honor, but to scourge him. two osier bundles of twigs----

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: shaking his fist at him. Woe unto you! But how say you----? THES. What is it you ask?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Where are the armsWhere are the armns: As Thesprio was his armour-bearer, this question cannot be considered as an impertinent one. of Stratippocles?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: I' faith, they've gone over to the enemy.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What, his arms?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Aye, and quickly too.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Do you say that seriously?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Seriously I say it; the enemy have got them.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: By my troth, a disgraceful affair.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Still, before now, other persons have done the same. This affair will turn out to his honorWill turn out to his honor: Schmieder thinks that in these words there is a covert allusion to the conduct of Terentius Varro, by whose bad management the Romans lost the battle of Cannæ, when fighting against Hannibal. The Senate, however, received him with open arms, "because he had not despaired of the state.".

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Because it has been so to others before.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Mulciber, I suppose, made the arms which Stratippocles had; they flew over to the enemyFlew over to the enemy: Plautus seems here to fancy that the arms made by Mulciber or Vulcan, for Achilles, were taken by Hector from Patroclus, when, in fact, they were made at the request of Thetis, for the purpose of avenging his death. He probably did not care to represent a slave and A camp-follower as being particularly correct in their knowledge of Homer..

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Why, then, e'en let this son of Thetis lose them; the daughters of Nereus will bring him others.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Only this must be looked to, that material may be found for the armourers, if in each campaign he yields a spoil to the enemy.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Have done now with these matters.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: You yourself make an end of them when you please.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Cease your enquiries then.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Say, where is Stratippocles himself?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: There is a reason, for which reason he has been afraid to come together with me.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Pray, what is it?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: He doesn't wish to see his father as yet.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: You shall hear; because he has purchased out of the spoil a young female captive of charming and genteel figure.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What is it I hear from you?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: That which I'm telling you.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Why has he purchased her?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: To please his fancy.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: How many fancies has this man? For assuredly, before he went away from home to the army, he himself commissioned me, that a music-girl whom he was in love with should be purchased of a Procurer for him. That I have managed to accomplish for him.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Whichever way the wind is at sea, Epidicus, in that direction the sail is shifted.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Woe unto wretched me! He has utterly undone me!

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: What's the meaning of this? What's the matter, pray?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Well now--she whom he has bought, at what sum has he purchased her?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: A very little.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: That I don't ask you.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: For how many minæ?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: holding up all his fingers four times. For so many.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Forty minæ?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: For that purpose, he borrowed the money on interest of a Banker at Thebes, at a didrachm for each silver mina per day.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Surprising!

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: This Banker, too, has come together with him, and is dunning for his money.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Immortal Gods! now I'm fairly done for!

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Why so, or.what's the matter, Epidicus?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: He has proved my ruin!

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Who? He who lost his arms.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: But why so?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Because he himself was every day sending me letters from the army--but I shall hold my tongue; it's best to do so. It's best for a man in servitude to know more than he says; that's true wisdom.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: On my faith, I don't understand why you are alarmed. You are frightened, Epidicus; I see it by your countenance. You seem here, in my absence, to have got into some scrape or other.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Can't you cease annoying me?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: I'll be off. Moves as if going.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Stand still; I'll not let you go from here. Holds him. THES. Why do you hold me back?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Is he in love with her whom he has purchased out of the spoil?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Do you ask me? He dotes to death upon her.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: The hide will be stripped from off my back.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: He loves her, too, more than ever he loved you.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: May Jupiter confound you!

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Let me go now; for he has forbidden me to go to our house; he ordered me to come here pointing to the house to our neighbour's, Chæribulus; there he bade me wait; he's about to come there himself.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: I'll tell you; because he doesn't wish to meet with or see his father, before he has paid down this money which is owing for her.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: O dear! an involved business, i' faith.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: Do let go of me, that I may now be off forthwith.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: When the old gentleman knows this, our ship will fairly founder.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: What matters it to me in what way you come to your end?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Because I don't wish to perish alone; I'd like you to perish with me, well-wisher with well-wisher.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: tearing himself away from EPIDICUS. Away with you from me to utter and extreme perdition with those terms of yours!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Be off, then, if you are in great haste about anything.

sp.speaker: THESPRIO
sp.p: aside. I never met with any person from whom I parted with greater pleasure. Goes into the house of CHÆRIBULUS.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: to himself. He's gone away from here; you are now alone. In what plight this matter is, you now see, Epidicus. Unless you have some resources in your own self, you are done for. Ruination so great is impending over you--unless you support yourself stoutly, you cannot hold up; to such a degree are mountains of misfortune threatening to tumble on you. Neither does any plan just now please me by means of which to find myself disengaged from my entanglement. To my misfortune, by my trickeries I have forced the old man to imagine that he was making purchase of his own daughter; whereas he has bought for his own son a music-girl whom he was fond of, and whom on his departure he commissioned me about. He now, to please his fancy, has brought another one from the army. I've lost my hide, for when the old man finds out that he has been played tricks with, he'll be flaying my back with twigs. But still, do you take all precautions. He stands still and thinKs. That's of no use! clearly this head of mine is addled! You are a worthless fellow, Epidicus. In another tone. What pleasure have you in being abusive? Because you are forsaking yourself. What am I to do? Do you ask me the question? Why you yourself, in former days, were wont to lend advice to others. Well, well; something must be found out. But why delay to go meet the young man, that I may know how the matter stands? And here he is himself. He is in a grave mood. He's coming with Chæribulus, his year's-mate. I'll step aside here, whence at my leisure I'll follow their discourse. He steps aside.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: I've told you all the matter, Chæribulus, and I have fully disclosed to you the sum of my griefs and loves.

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: You are foolish, Stratippocles, beyond your age and lineage. Does it shame you, because you have bought a captive girl, born of good family, from among the spoil? Who will there be to impute it as a fault to you?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Through doing this, I've found that those who are envious are all enemies to me; but I've never offered violenceNever offered violence: This is a very important passage, as it relieves the Audience from the apprehension they might otherwise feel in the Fifth Act, that Stratippocles had unconsciously been guilty of incest. or criminal assault against her chastity.

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: Then, so far, in my opinion at least, you are a still more deserving man, inasmuch as you are temperate in your passion.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: He effects nothing who consoles a desponding man with his words: he is a friend, who, in dubious circumstances, aids in deed when deeds are necessary.

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: What do you wish me to do?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: To lend me forty minæ of silver, to be paid to the Banker from whom I borrowed it on interest.

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: On my word, if I had it, I would not deny you.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: What then does it signify your being bounteous in talk, if all aid in the matterIf all aid in the matter: The same sentiment occurs in the Trinummus, l. 439. is dead outright.

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: Why faith, I myself am quite wearied and distracted with being dunned.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: I had rather my friends of that sort were thrust into a furnace than into litigationInto litigation: "Quam Foro." Literally, "than in the Forum." He plays on the resemblance of the words "furno," "oven" or "furnace," and "Foro," the "Forum." He had rather see his friends dead outright, than worried by their creditors.. But now I could wish to buy me the assistance of Epidicus at a weighty price, a fellow whom I'll hand over well-liquored with stripes to the bakerTo the baker: For the purpose of taking his place at the hand-mill for grinding corn, which was probably done in the same building where the bread was baked, and was a most laborious operation., unless he this day finds me forty minæ before I've mentioned to him the last syllable of the sum.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: apart. The matter's all right; he promises well; he'll keep faith, I trust. Ironically. Without any expenditure of my own, an entertainmentAn entertainment: As already mentioned, "symbola" was a club entertainment, or pic-nic (in the original sense of the word), where each provided his own share of the provisions. is already provided for my shoulder-blades. I'll accost the man. He goes up to STRATIPPOCLES. The servant Epidicus wishes health to his master Stratippocles, on his arrival from abroad.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: turning round. Where is he?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Here he is; I'm delighted that you have returned safe.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: I believe you as much in that as I do myself.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Have you been well all along?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: I've been free from disease; in mind I've been ailing.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: As regarded myself, I've taken care of what you entrusted to me; it has been obtained; the female captive has been bought, about which matter you were sending me letters so often.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: You've lost all your labour.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: But why have I lost it?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Because she is not dear to my heart, nor does she please me.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What means it, then, that you gave me such strict injunctions, and sent letters to me?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Formerly I did love her; but now another passion influences my heart.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I' faith, it is a shocking thing for that to be unpleasant for a man which you have managed well for him; where I've done well, I've in reality done ill, since love has shifted sides.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: I wasn't right in my mind when I sent those letters to you.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Is it proper that I should be the atonement for your folly, so as for you to substitute my back as the scape-goatAs the scape-goat: "Succidanea" was a term applied to a victim, substituted in place of another which had not given favourable omens. for your folly?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Why are we making words about that? This man pointing to himself has need of forty minæ, ready money, and in all haste, for him to pay a Banker, and speedily too.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Only tell me from what quarter you wish me to get them. From what banker am I to seek them?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: From where you like. But if I don't finger them before sunset, don't you enter my house; off with yourself to the mill.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: You easily say that without risk and concern, and with a gay heart. I know our floggers; I feel the pain when I'm beaten.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: How say you now? Will you suffer me to destroy myself?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Don't do that. I'll cope with this peril and bold attempt in preference.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Now you please me; now do I commend you.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I'll submit to this in any way that's pleasing to you.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: What then is to be done about this music-girl?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Some method shall be found out; by some means I'll disengage myself; some way I shall get extricated.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: You are full of scheming; I know you of old.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: There is a rich Captain of EubœaCaptain of Eubœa: The Captain is elsewhere called a Rhodian. Probably it is meant that Rhodes was the place of his birth, and the island of Eubœa that of his residence., abounding in plenty of gold, who, when he knows that that one was bought for you, and that this other one has been brought here, will forthwith be entreating you, of his own accord, to transfer that other one to him. But where is she whom you have brought with you?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: I shall have her here just now.

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: What are we now doing here?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Let's go in-doors here at your house, that, for the present, we may pass this day merrily. They go into the house of CHÆRIBULUS.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: to himself. Go in-doors; I'll now callI'll now call: -159. Echard's adaptation of these two lines is so quaint, that it is worth transcribing. "In the meantime must I have a committee of the whole house, to consider of ways and means for the raising supplies to carry on this vigorous war." a council in my heart to adopt measures about this money business, against whom, in especial, war is to be declared, and out of whom I'm to get the money. Epidicus, consider what you are to do; thus suddenly has this business been thrown upon you. But now you must not be slumbering, nor have you any leisure for delay. Now must you be daring! 'Tis my fixed determination to lay siege to the old man. I'll go indoors; I'll tell the young man, my master's son, not to walk abroad here, or come anywhere in the way of the old gentleman. Goes into the house of CHÆRIBULUS.

div1.stage: Enter APÆCIDES and PERIPHANES, from the house of the former.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Mostly all menMostly all men: Apæcides has been talking in-doors with Periphanes about his supposed daughter who has lately come home, and is recommending him to atone to Philippa for his conduct to her, by marrying her. It is supposed that Terence had this passage in view in the Andria, l. 637-8. are ashamed when they have no occasion to be; when they ought to be ashamed, then does shame forsake them, when there's a necessity for their being ashamed. That man, in fact, are you. What is there to be ashamed of in your bringing home a wife, poor, but born of good family? Especially her, whose daughter you say this girl is, who is at your house?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I have some regard for my sonRegard for my son: It was looked upon as a disgraceful thing for a father with grown-up sons to marry again, and thereby introduce a mother- in-law into his family. Apæcides blames Periphanes for this scruple, and hints to him that he ought not to be more ashamed on account of his son, than of his late wife, who, being dead, and for whom he had no hearty liking, could not make him blush at a second marriage..

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: But, i' faith, the wife whom you buried I thought you had felt some respect for; whose tomb as oft as you see, you straightway sacrifice victims to Orcus; and not without reason, in fact, since you've been allowed to get the better of her by surviving her.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Ah me! I was a Hercules while she was with me; and, upon my faith, the sixth labourThe sixth labour: The sixth labour of Hercules was his combat with the Amazons, when he took Antiope or Hippolyts, their queen, and carried off her girdle. was not more difficult to Hercules than the one that fell to my lot.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: I' faith, money's a handsome dowry.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Troth, so it is, which isn't encumbered with a wife.

div1.stage: Enter EPIDICUS, from the house of CHÆRIBULUS, softly crossing the stage.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: at the door, as he enters. Hist! hist! be silent, and have good courage; with a fair omen have I come out of doors, the bird upon the left handBird upon the left hand: Among the Romans the Augur looked to the South, having the East on his left hand, which was considered the auspicious quarter. The Greeks considered birds on the left hand an ill omen.. Pointing to his head. I've got a sharp knife, with which to embowel the old man's purse; but see! here he is before the house of Apæcides, the two old fellows, just as I want. Now I shall change me into a leech, and suck out the blood of these who are called the pillars of the Senate.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Let him be married at once.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: I approve of your design.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: For I've heard that he's entangled with love with a certain music-girl, I don't know who. At that I'm vexed to death.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: apart. By my troth, all the Deities do aid, amplify, and love me; really, these men themselves are pointing out to me the way by means of which I'm to get the money out of them. Now then, come, equip yourself, Epidicus, and throw your cloak about your neck suiting the action to the word, and pretend as though you had been in search of the man all the city over. On with it, if you are going to do it! He hurries past the OLD MEN as though he didn't see them, and calls out aloud. Immortal Gods! I do wish I could meet with Periphanes at home, whom I'm tired with searching for all over the city, throughout the doctors' shops, throughout the barbers' shops, in the gymnasium, and in the Forum, at the perfumers' shops and the butchers' stallsButchers' stalls: "Lanienas." Madame Dacier thinks that this means a place where arms were sold, and the "lanistæ," or "gladiators" exercised themselves., and round about the bankers' shops. I'm become hoarse with enquiring; I've almost dropped down with running.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Epidicus!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: looking round. Who is it that's calling Epidicus back?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: It's I, Periphanes.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: And I, Apæcides.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: And I, indeed, am Epidicus. But, master, I find that you've both met me at the nick of time.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Wait, wait! puffs and blows; prithee, do let me get breath!

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: By all means, rest yourself.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I'm quite faint; I must recover my breath.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Do rest yourself at your leisure.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Lend me your attention. All the men of the army have been remanded home from ThebesRemanded home from Thebes: Madame Dacier supposes, and with fair reason, that in this Epidicus tells what really is the fact..

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Who knows for certain that this has been done?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I say that it has been done.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Are you sure of that?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I am sure of it.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Why are you sure of it?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Because I've seen the soldiers marching through the streets in shoals. They are bringing back their arms and their baggage-horses.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Very good indeed!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Then, what prisoners they've got with them! boys, girls, in twos and threes; another one has got five; there's a crowd in the streets; they are looking out each for his son.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I' troth, a business very well managed!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Then, filly as many of the courtesans as there are in the whole city were going decked out each to meet her lover; they were going to trap them; that's the fact, inasmuch as I gave especial attention to it; several of these had with them nets beneath their garments. When I came to the harbour, forthwith I espied her waiting there, and with her were four music-girls.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: With whom, Epidicus?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: With her whom your son has been loving and doting on for years, with whom he's making all haste to ruin credit, property, himself, and yourself. She was on the lookout for him at the harbour.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Just see the sorceress now!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: But decked out, sparkling with gold, and adorned so splendidly! so nicely! so fashionably!

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What was she drest in? Was it a royal robe, or was it a plain dress?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: A skylight oneA skylight one: "Impluviatam." Echard's Note to this passage is much to the purpose. "The word 'impluvium' signifies a square open place which the Romans had in their houses to receive rain for their use; or a square courtyard, that received the rain at four water-spouts; from whence a habit they had, made with four sides or four pieces, was called 'vestimentum impluviatum.' Here Epidicus takes occasion from this to admire at a woman's being able to wear a courtyard on her back. Periphanes, carrying on the humour, tells him 'tis no wonder, since they frequently wear whole houses and lands, meaning the value of them." The word "impluvium" has been previously rendered "skylight," in the present Translation. See the Notes to the Miles Gloriosus, l. 159, where Periplecomenus complains of Sceledrus looking down his "impluvium" from the top of the house. The garment may, however, not improbably have been called "impluviatum," from its being of a greyish, or rain colour., according as these women coin names for garments.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What! was she dressed in a skylight?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What's there wonderful in that? As though many women didn't go through the streets decked out with farms upon them. But when the tax is demanded, they declare it cannot be paidThey declare it cannot be paid: He means that their dupes or lovers cannot pay their taxes.; while to these hussies, to whom a larger tax is paid, it can be paid. Why, what new names every year these women are finding for their clothing--the thin tunic, the thick tunic, your fulled linen cloth, chemises, bordered shifts' the marigold or saffron-coloured dress, the under-petticoat or else the light vermilion dress, the hood, the royal or the foreign robe, the wave patternThe wave pattern: "Cumatile," from the Greek ku=ma, "a wave." These dresses were so called, probably, from their being undulated, or, as we call it, "watered." Ovid, in the Art of Love, B. 8, l. 177, speaks of dresses called "undulatæ," "resembling the waves;" as also does Varro. Some Commentators think that "undulatæ" means "sea-green," and Schmieder takes "cumatile" to mean the same. From its juxtaposition with "plumatile," "feather-pattern," it would seem that the pattern rather than the colour is alluded to. "Plumatile" is considered by some simply to mean embroidered; and "plumata" is clearly used in that sense by Lucan in the Pharsalia, B. 10, l. 125. For a list of the Roman ladies' dresses, see the Aulularia, l. 463, et seq. or the feather-pattern, the wax or the apple-tint. The greatest nonsense! From dogs, too, do they even take the names.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p:
They call one the LaconianThe Laconian: Probably the garments had their name from their resemblance to the colour of this breed of dogs. They were imported from Laconia, and hence called "Laconici." From an expression in the Epodes of Horace, Ode VI., l. 5-6, they appear to have been used as shepherds' dogs; but Warner in a Note to his Translation, supposes them to have been of the greyhound species, So, in Shakspeare's Midsummer Night's Dream. Act IV., Sc. 1, Theseus says:
My hounds are bred out of the Spartan kind,
So flewed, so, sanded. These names compel men to make auctions.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: But do you say on as you commenced.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Two other women behind me began to speak thus between themselves; I, like my wont, went away a little distance from them; I pretended that I wasn't attending to their talk: I didn't quite hear all, and still I wasn't deceived in a word they said.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I long to hear it.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Then one of them said to the other with whom she was talking----

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Be quiet then, that you may hear. After they had caught sight of her whom your son is dying for: "Prithee, how happily and luckily has it befallen that woman for her lover to be wishing to set her free." "Who is he?" said the other. She mentioned Stratippocles.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Troth now, I'm undone; what is it I hear of you?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: That which really took place. After this, I myself, when I heard them talking, began again to draw closer towards them little by little, as though the crowd of people was pushing me, whether I would or no.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Then the one asked the other, "How do you know?" "Why, because a letter has been brought her to-day from Stratippocles; that he has borrowed money on interest from a banker at Thebes; that it is ready, and he himself has brought it for that purpose."

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Tell on--I'm undone!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: She said that she had heard so from her and from the letter which she had seen.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What am I to do now? I ask your advice, Apæcides.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Let us find some clever, useful expedient; for he, indeed, will either be here just now, or is here already.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: If it were right for me to be wiser than you, I could give you some good advice, which you will praise, I fancy, both of you----

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Then where is it, Epidicus?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Yes, and useful for this purpose,

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Why do you hesitate to mention it?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: It's proper for yourselves, who are the wiser, to be the first to speak, and for me to speak afterwards.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Aye, aye, of course--come, say on.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: But you'll laugh at me.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: On my word, we will not do so.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Well then, if it pleases you, use my advice; if it doesn't please you, find better. There's neither sowing nor reapingNeither sowing nor reaping: "Mihi istic nec seritur nec metitur." This proverbial saying (so well known to every student of the Eton Grammar) merely means, "I have no interest whatever in the matter." for me in this matter; only that I do wish the same that you wish.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I return you thanks. Make us partakers in your wisdom.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Let a wife at once be chosen for your son; and so take vengeance on this music-girl whom he wants to liberate, and who is corrupting him for you; and so let it be managed, that even until her dying day she may remain a slave.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: It ought to be so managed.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I am ready to do anything, so long only as this may be brought about

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Well then, now there's an opportunity of doing so, before he comes into the city, as to-morrow he will be here; to-day he will not have come.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I do know, because another person told me, who came from there, that he would be here in the morning.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Then say you what we are to do.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I'm of opinion that you ought to do thus: you must pretend as though you were desirous to give her liberty to the music-girl for your own whim, and as though you were violently in love with her.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: To what advantage does that tend?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Do you ask that? Why, that you may purchase her beforehand with money, before your son comes, and may say that you bought her to set her at liberty----

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: When she's bought, you must remove her somewhere out of the city; unless your own feelings are any way opposed.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: O no, skilfully suggested.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: But what say you, Apæcides?

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Why, what should I? Except that I think you've contrived it very cleverly.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Then, in consequence, all thoughts of marriage with her will be removed from him, so that he will make no difficulties as to what you wish.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Long life to you, wise as you are, it really does please us.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Do you then skilfully do whatever you are going to do.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I' faith, you speak to the purpose.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I have found, too, how this suspicion may be removed from yourself.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Let me know it.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: You shall know it; just listen.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: He's come with a breast full of counsel.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: There's need of a person to carry the money there for the music-girl; but there's no equal necessity for yourself to do it.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Lest he should think you are doing it for the sake of your son----

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Cleverly thought of!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: By which means you'll keep him away from her; lest any difficulty might arise by reason of that suspicion.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What person shall we find suited to this purpose?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: pointing to APÆCIDES. He will be the best; he will be able to take all due precautions, as he understands the laws and ordinances.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Epidicus, receive my thanks. But I'll attend to this with all care.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I'll find him and bring him here to you, to whom the music-girl belongs; and I'll take the money along with him. Pointing to APÆCIDES.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: For how much, at the lowest, can she be bought?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What, she? Perhaps she might possibly be bought at the lowest for forty minæ; but if you give me more, I shall return it. There's no trickery in this matter. This money, too, of yours won't be locked up ten days.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Why, because another young man is dying with love for this woman, one abounding in money, a great warrior, a Rhodian, a spoiler of his foesA Rhodian, a spoiler of his foes: The Rhodians were considered wealthy, proud, and boastful., a boaster; he'll buy her of you, and give the money with pleasure. You only do it; there's a large profit for you here.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I really pray the Gods it may be so.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: You'll obtain your prayer.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Why then, don't you go in-doors and bring the money out here? I'll go visit the Forum. Epidicus, do you come thither.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: to APÆCIDES. Don't you go away from there before I come to you.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: I'll wait till then.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: to EPIDICUS. Do you follow me in- doors.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Go and count it out; I'll not detain you at all. (Exit APÆCIDES, and PERIPHANES goes into his house.)

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: to himself. I do think that in the Attic land there is no spot of land so fertile as is this Periphanes of ours; why, from the locked and sealed-up money-chest I summon forth silver just as much as I please. But this, i' troth, I am afraid of, that if the old man should come to know it, he'll be making parasites of elm-twigsParasites of elm-twigs: He alludes to the propensity of Parasites for devouring to the bone all who came in their way., to be shaving me quite clean. But one matter and consideration disturbs me--what music-girl, one that goes out on hire, I'm to show to Apæcides. He muses. And that as well I've got: this morning the old gentleman bade me bring for him on hire some music-girl to his house here, to sing for him while he was performing a sacrificePerforming a sacrifice: It was the custom, while private person were sacrificing to the Lares or household Gods, to have music performed upon the harp or the pipe.. She shall be hired, and be instructed beforehand in what way she's to prove herself cunning towards the old man. I'll away in-doors; I'll get the money out of the swindled old fellow. He goes into the house of PERIPHANES.

div1.stage: Enter STRATIPPOCLES and CHÆRIBULUS, from the house of the latter.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: I'm distractedly in suspense and worn to the heart with waiting how the fair promises of Epidicus will turn out for me. I've been tormented too long. Whether there is to be anything, or whether there is not, I wish to know.

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: For all these resources you may still seek some other resources for yourself. For my part, I knew at the first, or the instant, that there was no help for you in himThat there was no help for you in him: "Nullam tibi esse in illo copiam.".

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Upon my faith, I'm ruined!

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: You act absurdly in tormenting yourself in mind. By my troth, if I should catch him, I would never allow that slave of a fellow to be laughing at us with impunity.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: What can you expect him to do, you, who have such great wealth at home, and have not a coin of it, as you say, and have in yourself no resources for your friend?

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: I' faith, if I had had it, I should have proffered it with pleasure; but something in some mannerSomething in some manner: This admirably shows how hard up the stingy Chæribulus is for an excuse., in some way, in some direction, from some person, some hope I have for you, that there'll be some good fortune for you to share with me.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Woe to you, you sneaking fellowYou sneaking fellow: "Murcide." Some editions have "muricide," "you mouse-killing fellow;" a capital name for a sordid, miserable creature..

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: Why does it please you to abuse me?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Why, because you are prating to me about something in some manner, from somewhere or other, from some persons, that nowhere exists, and I won't admit it to my ears. Of no more assistance are you unto me than he who never yet has been born. They stand near the door of the house of CHÆRIBULUS.

div1.stage: Enter EPIDICUS, from the house of PERIPHANES, with a bag of money round his neck.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: to PERIPHANES, within the house. You've done your duty then; it now befits me to do mine. Through this care of mine, you may be allowed to be at ease. In a lower voice. This, in fact, is now lost to you; don't at all be setting your hopes on it. Holding some of the coins in his hands. How very shining it is! You only trust me for that. This way I'm going to act, this way my forefathers have acted before me. O ye immortal Gods, what a brilliant day you have bestowed upon me in this how propitious and how favourable to my requests! But why do I delay to take my departure hence, that I may bear this supply with lucky auspices to the colonyTo the colony: He means the house of Chæribulus, which has just been peopled by his master.. I'm delaying while I'm standing here. But what means this? Before the house I see the two companions, my master and Chæribulus. Accosting them. What are you doing? Take this, will you. Gives STRATIPPOCLES the bag of money.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: How much is there in this?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: As much as is enough, and more than enough; a superabundance; I've brought more by ten minæ than you owe to the Banker. So long as I please and obey you, I value my own back at a straw.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: But why so?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Because I shall make your father a bag-murdererA bag- murderer: "Perenticidam." A word coined by the author for the occasion, on account of its resemblance to "parenticida," "a parricide.".

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: What kind of expression is that?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I don't at all care for your old-fashioned and every-day words; you chouse by purses fullChouse by purses full: Echard gives a particular meaning te this passage, and Warner seems to adopt his notion, which certainly seems farfetched. The former says, in a Note, "Epidicus here carries on the fancy of 'perenticida,' and 'parenticide, and the Poet has luckily hit upon a line that exactly agrees with either. For the common punishment of parricides was to put them into a sack with a cock, a serpent, and an ape, and then throw them into the river. Now the ward 'ductare' signifies equally 'to bring a man into punishment,' or 'to cheat him;' so that the phrase 'peratim ductare' is the same thing; only 'follis' was a much larger sack than 'pera.'" M. Guiet considers this passage to be spurious., but I'll chouse by bags full. For the procurer took away a whole lot of money for the music-girl (I paid it; with these hands I counted it out), her whom your father supposes to be his own daughter. Now, again, that your father may be deceived, and assistance be provided for you, I've discovered a method. In such a way have I persuaded the old gentleman--and had a talk to this effect, that, when you returned, you might not have possession of herPossession of her: Madame Dacier is of opinion that some lines are wanting here. Echard and Warner are also of that opinion.----

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Bravo!--bravo!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: She's now at your houseShe's now at your house: That is, the first mistress of Stratippocles is at his father's house personating the lost daughter. in place of her.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Now he has given me Apæcides by way of guarantee in this matter (he's waiting for me at the Forum), as if to seem the purchaser.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Not a bad precaution!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: The cautious man's now taken in himself; your own father himself placed this purse around my neckThis purse around my neck: Purses containing large sums of money were generally slung round the neck by a string. See the Aulularia, l. 258 Asinaria, l. 661; and Truculentus, l. 648.. He's making preparation, that immediately on your arrival home you shall be married.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: In one way only will he persuade me; if Orcus takes her away from me, who has been brought with me.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Now I've hit upon this scheme: I'll go by myself alone to the procurer's house; I'll instruct him, if any one comes to him, to say that the money has been paid him for the music-girl; inasmuch as, the day before yesterday, I paid it down with my own hands for this mistress of yours, whom your father takes to be his own daughter. Then the procurer, unknowingly, will be staking his accursed head, as though he had received the money for her who has now been brought here together with you.

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: You are more versatile than a potter's-wheel.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Now I'll get ready some artful music-girl, who's hired at a didrachm, to pretend that she has been purchased, and cleverly to trick the two old fellows: Apæcides, together with her, will bring her to your father.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: How adroitly managed!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Her, prepared beforehand with my devices, and provided with my schemes, I shall send to him. But I'm talking at too great length; you have delayed me too long: you now know these things how they are to be; I'll be off.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Success attend you! Exit EPIDICUS.

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: He is very clever at artful tricks.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Indeed, by his plans, he has saved me, that's sure.

sp.speaker: CHÆR.
sp.p: Let's go hence into my house.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Yes, and a little more joyfully than I came out of your house, by the courage and conduct of Epidicus, do I return into camp with the spoil. They go into the house.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p:
to herself. Not only for the sake of the face were it right for men to have a mirror for themselves wherein to look at their faces; but one with which they might be enabled to examine the heart of discretion, and therefore be able to examine the resources of the mind; when they had looked in that, they might afterwards consider how they had once passed their lives in youth. Just as myself, for instance, who, for the sake of my son, began to torment myself in mind, as though my son had been guilty of some offence against, me, or as though my own misdeeds had not been most heavy in my youth. In truth, we old fellows are out of our senses sometimes. This, in my own opinion at least, has proved advantageous. But my friend Apæcides is coming with the spoil. I'm glad that the negotiator has returned safe.
Enter APÆCIDES, with a MUSIC-GIRL.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: How goes it?

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: The Gods and Goddesses are favouring you.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: The omen pleases me.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: A person with whom all things go on prosperously. But do you order her to be taken in-doors.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: going to the door of his house, and calling. Hallo there! come out of doors here, some one. A SERVANT comes out. Take that woman into the house! And, do you hear?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: What do you desire?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Take care you don't permit this woman to associate with my daughter, or to see her. Now do you understand? I wish her to be shut up apart in that little chamber; there's a great difference between the manners of a maiden and a courtesan. The SERVANT leads the MUSIC-GIRL into the house.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: You speak cleverly and judiciously; each man cannot keep too strict a guard upon the chastity of his daughter. Upon my faith, we certainly did forestall this woman from your son just in time.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Because another person told me that he had just seen your son here.

sp.speaker: PERT.
sp.p: I' troth, he was stirring in this business.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Upon my faith, it really is so, clearly. You really have a clever servant, and worth any price.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: At his weight in gold he would not be dear.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: How well he keptHow well he kept: The cunning of Epidicus is admirably shown here. He pretends to the old man that they together are deceiving the Music-girl, while, in reality, he is imposing on the old man. that Music-girl quite in ignorance that she was purchased for you; so full of joke and fun did he bring her hither along with him.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: It's wonderful how that could be managed.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: He said that you were going to offer a sacrifice at home for your son, because he had returned safe from Thebes.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: He hit upon the right thing.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Yes, and he himself told her that she had been hired to assist you here in the sacrifice. He said that you were about to perform it, and that you had a sacrifice at home. But I then made pretence that I was ignorant, as it were, inasmuch as I made myself out half-wittedMade myself out half-witted: This in his wisdom he pretended that she might not fancy that he was a cunning fellow, going to put a trick upon her, in combination with Epidicus..

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Why yes; it was right to do so.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: An important trial of a friend is going on at the Forum; I want to go as his advocate.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Go, and when you have leisure, return to me mediately.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: I'll be here just now. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: to himself. Nothing is there more opportune to man than a friend in need; without labour of your own, what you want is done nevertheless. If I had commissioned any one upon this business, a less skilful person, and less fitted for this matter, he would have been gulled; and so, grinning with his white teeth, my son would have most deservedly laughed at me. But who is this I see coming this way, that with his swaggering makes his scarf to be streaming in the wind? He stands aside.

div1.stage: Enter a CAPTAIN, with his SERVANT.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: to his SERVANT. Take care not to pass by any house without asking where lives the old gentleman, Periphanes of PlotheaPeriphanes of Plothea: "Plothenius." Most of the editions have here "Platænius" "of Platæa." As this was in Bœotia, the other is far more likely to be the right reading, Plothea being a Demus of Attica.. Take care that you don't return to me without knowing it.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: coming forward. Young man, if I point out to you the person whom you are in search of, what thanks shall I get of you?

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: In arms, by the might of war, I've deserved that all people ought to give me thanks.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: You haven't found out, young man, a tranquil spot where to recount your virtues as you wish; for, if an inferior vaunts his battles to a superior, by his lips they become soiled; but this Periphanes of Plothea whom you are seeking, I am he, if you want him for anything.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: Him, you mean, who in his youth among kings in arms, by his skill in war, gained vast wealth?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Aye, if you were to hear of my achievements, drop ping your hands you would run off home.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: I' faith, I'm rather in search of one to whom to speak of my own, than of one to be speaking of his to me.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: This is not the place for it. Do you then look out for another person, into whom to stuff your scraps of nonsenseYour scraps of nonsense: "Centones." These were properly patchwork tales, or poems, made up of scraps from various works.. Aside. And yet this is folly, for me to impute that to him as a fault, which I myself used to do in my youth when I was a soldier; in recounting my battles I used to tear out men's ears by the roots, when I had once begun.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: Lend your attention, that you may learn what I've come to you about. I've heard that you have purchased my mistress.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: aside. Heyday! now at last I know who he is; the officer whom Epidicus was telling me about a short time since. To the OFFICER. Young man, it is as you say; I have purchased her.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: I want a few words with you, if it is not inconvenient to you.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Upon my faith, I don't know whether it's convenient or not, until perhaps you say what you want.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: I want you to transfer her to me, and take the ransom.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: You may have her.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: But why should I hesitate to speak out to you? I wish at once to make her my freed-woman, that she may be my mistressThat she may be my mistress: The swaggering, careless character of the Captain, is admirably depicted here, as he does not hesitate to tell a perfect stranger, and him an aged man, his intentions, at the possible risk of shocking him..

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I'll make short work with you; she was bought for me for fifty minæ of silver; if sixty minæ are paid down to me, I'll let the damsel employ your holidaysEmploy your holidays: The "feriæ," or "holidays," are mentioned in the Captivi, l. 473. See the Note to the passage., and so assuredly so, that, if you like, you may remove her from this country.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: Is she then purchased by me?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: On those terms you may have her. You have made a good bargain. Going to the door of his house. Hallo there! bring out of doors the Music-girl you took in. The harp, too, as well, that was thrown in with her, I'll make you a present of it for nothing. MUSIC-GIRL.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: taking her by the hand and leading her to the CAPTAIN. Come, take her, please.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: What madness possesses you? What mystery are you devising for me? Why don't you order the Music-girlOrder the Music-girl: Periphanes has ordered the girl who has just come, and whom he takes to be Acropolistis, to be brought out; whereas the Captain is in love with the first, who is passing for the old gentleman's daughter and this mistake occasions the dispute to be brought from in-doors?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Why, this is the Music-girl. There's no other one here.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: You can't impose on me. Why don't you bring out here the Music-girl Acropolistis?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: This, I tell you, is she.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: This, I tell you, is not she. Do you suppose that I can't know my own mistress?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: It was this Music-girl, I tell you, for whom my son was dying with love.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: This is not she.

sp.speaker: PERT.
sp.p: How, not she?

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: It is not.

sp.speaker: PERT.
sp.p: Where in the world, then, does, she come from? For my part, i' faith, I certainly paid the money for her.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: Foolishly paid, I guess, and a mighty mistake.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Nay, but this is she; for I sent the servant who is in the habit of attending my son; he himself this moment purchased the Music-girl.

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: Well then, this fellow has cut you up joint by joint, old gentleman, this servant of yours.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: How, cut me up?

sp.speaker: A CAPTAIN
sp.p: Such is my suspicion; for she has been palmed upon you for that Music-girl. Old gentleman, you've been bubbled clearly and cleverly. I shall now go seek her wherever she is. Warrior, farewell! (Exeunt the OFFICER and SERVANT.)

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: stamnping with rage. Bravo, bravo! Epidicus You're a clever fellow! You have fought well--you're a man! you've wiped my nose when snivelling, worthless fellow that I am! To the MUSIC-GIRL. Did Apæcides purchase you to-day of the procurer? A pause. Come now, tell me.

sp.speaker: MUS.-G.
sp.p: I never heard of that person before to-day, nor, indeed, was any one able to purchase me for any money; I've been free now for more than five years.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What business have you, then, at my house?

sp.speaker: MUS.-G.
sp.p: You shall hear; I came, being hired to perform for an old gentleman while he was sacrificing.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I do confess that I am the most worthless of all men in Athens of Attica. But do you know Acropolistis the Music-girl?

sp.speaker: MUS.-G.
sp.p: As well as my own self.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Where does she live?

sp.speaker: MUS.-G.
sp.p: Since she has been made free, I don't know for certain.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Well now, I should like to know who has made her free, if you know?

sp.speaker: MUS.-G.
sp.p: That which I have heard, you shall hear; I heard that StratippoclesI heard that Stratippocles: She discloses to him what she has heard as the fact, and which is the real state of the case. Although Acropolistis is in his house, in the character of his daughter, he, not knowing who she really is, is alarmed at hearing that his son has procured her liberation, which he has just taken so much pains to prevent., the son of Periphanes, had provided in his absence that she should be made free.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: By heavens, I'm undoneI'm undone: Having now detected this piece of roguery of which Epidicus has been guilty., most clearly, if these things are true. Epidicus has disembowelled my purse!

sp.speaker: MUS.-G.
sp.p: I've heard to that effect. Do you want me for anything else?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Away to perdition in the veriest torments, and off this instant!

sp.speaker: MUS.-G.
sp.p: Won't you give me back my harp?

sp.speaker: PERT.
sp.p: Neither harp nor pipes. Make haste, then, and escape from here, if the Gods love you!

sp.speaker: MUS.-G.
sp.p: I'll be off. At a future time, however, you'll restore it, with the greater disgraceWith the greater disgrace: Probably by being sued, and obliged to give it up, whether he will or no. to yourself. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: to himself. What now? Shall I, who have been placed before so many edictsBefore so many edicts: "Qui in tantis positus sum sententiis." This passage has been explained various ways; but Madame Dacier seems justified in thinking that Gronovius has found the right meaning, and that the allusion is to the custom of placing the name of the proposer at the head of the yhfi/smata, or public edicts of the Greeks; this of course implied that the proposer was a man of standing, and of some fair pretensions to a reputation for wisdom., allow him to get with impunity? No; even though as much again should be required to be lost, I'll lose it rather than allow myself to be held in derision with impunity and plundered by them. That I should have been thus cheated openly to my face, and that I should have been set at nought before this Apæcides, who is famed as being the framer and founder of all the laws and ordinances! He too declares that he is a wise man! that the hammer, forsooth, should be wiser than the handleThan the handle: He seems to compare Apæcides to the head of the hammer, and himself to the handle, and says that they are equally outwitted. He probably implies thereby that he has been in the habit of giving the impetus to Apæcides in the same way that the handle of the hammer does to the head.! He stands aside.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: to herself. If a mortal being has aught of misery, through which, miserable creature, to be wretched from the heart, that same do I experience, for whom full many a woe unites in the same spot, which, all, at the same instant are beating against my breast. A multitude of troubles keep me in suspense. Poverty and misery alarm the thoughts of my heart; nor have I anywhere a spot of safety where to fix my hopes; in such a way has my daughter fallen into the power of the enemyInto the power of the enemy: Though this has happened probably some time since, Philippa has not had an opportunity till now of coming in search of her daughter, by reason of the continuance of war. As soon as peace is made, she repairs to Athens,; nor do I know where she now is.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: apart. Who is this woman coming from a distance with a breast filled with alarms, and who thus bewails her lot?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: to herself. It was told me that Periphanes was living in this neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: apart. She's mentioning me; need of hospitality has befallen her, I suppose.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: to herself. I would be very willing to give a reward to any one who would point me out that man, or where he dwells.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: apart. I recognize her; for I think I have seen her before; where, I know not. Is it, or is it not she, whom my mind suspects her to be?

sp.speaker: >PHIL.
sp.p: seeing him. Good Gods! I have seen this person before!

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: to himself. It surely is she, a poor woman whom I remember having an intrigue with at Epidaurus.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: to herself. Surely it is he, who at Epidaurus first violated my maiden modesty.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: to himself. She who had the daughter by me whom I've now got at home.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: to herself. What if I accost him?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: to himself. I don't know whether to make up to her. If this is she----

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: to herself. But if it is the man, as length of years renders me doubtful----

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: to himself. Length of time renders my mind uncertain. But if it is she, whom with some doubt I conjecture it to be, I'll accost her circumspectly.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: to herself. A woman's artfulness must be employed by me.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: to himself. I'll address her.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: to herself. I'll bring my powers of conversation to bear against him.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: accosting her. Health to you!

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: That health I accept for me and mine.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What besides?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Health to yourself; what you lent me, I return.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I don't impeach your punctuality. Don't I know you?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: If I know you, I'll move your feelings, so that you shall know me.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Where have I been in the habit of seeing you?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: You are unfairly hard upon me.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Because you think it right that I should be the prompter of your memory.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: You speak to the purpose.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: You say what's strange to me, Periphanes.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Ah now! that's better. Do you remember, Philippa----

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Yes, I remember that.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: At Epidaurus----

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Ah! you have moistened my burning breast with a little drop of comfort.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: How I relieved the poverty of you, a poor young maiden, and your mother?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: What, are you he who for your own gratification brought heavy troubles upon me?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I am he. Health to you.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: I am in health, since I see you in health.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Give me your hand.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: extending her hand, which he takes. Take it--you hold by the hand a woman distrest and full of woes.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What is it that disturbs your features?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: The daughter whom I had by you----

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: When I had brought her up, I lost her; she fell into the hands of the enemy.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Keep your mind in quiet and at rest. Why look, she's here at my house safe and sound. For immediately I heard from my servant that she was a captive, instantly I gave the money for her to be purchased; he managed this affair as discreetly and frugally as in other matters he is egregiously--dishonest.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Let me see her, whether it is she or no.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: going to the door of his house. Hallo there! you--Canthara, this instant bid my daughterBid my daughter: "Acropolistidem" is here inserted in the editions evidently by mistake, and is purposely omitted in this Translation. It was probably inserted by some careless or injudicious transcriber in the middle ages, in the place of "Telestidem," as Periphanes knows the girl in his house as Telestis, and fancies that she is his daughter. At the same time he knows that Acropolistis is the name of his son's mistress, whom he has so recently tried unsuccessfully (as he supposes) to get into his power. come out before the house, that she may see her mother.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: My spirits now at last return to me.

sp.speaker: ACROPOLISTIS
sp.p: Why is it, father, that you have called me out before the house?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: That you may see and accost your mother, and wish her health on her arrival, and give her kisses.

sp.speaker: ACROPOLISTIS
sp.p: looking about. What mother of mine?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: pointing to PHILIPPA. She who, half dead, is following your gaze.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Who is this that you are requesting to kiss me?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Your own daughter.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: What, she?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: She.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: What--am I to kiss her?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Why not, her who was born of you?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Man, you are mad.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What, I?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Yes, you.

sp.speaker: PERT.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Because this woman--I neither know nor understand who she is, nor have I beheld her with my eyes before this day.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I know why you are mistaken; because this woman has her dress and ornaments changed.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Puppies have one smellHave one smell: She means that all animals have an instinct by which they recognize their own young., pigs quite another; I say that I do not know her, who she is.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: stamping with rage. Oh! by our trust in Gods and men, what is this? Am I following the calling of a Procurer, to be keeping strange women in my house, and to be emptying my house of my money? To ACROPOLISTIS. What are you to be calling me your father and kissing me? Why stand you stupidly there? Why do you keep silent?

sp.speaker: ACROPOLISTIS
sp.p: What do you want me to say?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: pointing to PHILIPPA. She denies that she is your mother.

sp.speaker: ACROPOLISTIS
sp.p: Don't let her be so, if she don't choose. For my own part, whether she likes it or not, I shall be my mother's daughter still. It isn't right for me to compel this woman to be my mother if she doesn't like.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Why then did you call me father?

sp.speaker: ACROPOLISTIS
sp.p: That is your own fault, not mine; ought I not to call you father when you call me daughter? Her too, as well pointing to PHILIPPA if she were to call me daughter, I should call mother. She declares that I am not her daughter; then she is not my mother. In fine, this is no fault of mine; what I've been taught, I've told you all of it. Epidicus was my instructor.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I'm undone! I've upset my waggonI've upset my waggon: Evidently a proverbial expression borrowed from rustic life. "To upset a man's apple-cart," is used in cant phrase-ology in our day, as meaning to do a person a disservice.!

sp.speaker: ACROPOLISTIS
sp.p: Have I done anything amiss towards that?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Upon my faith, if I ever hear you call me father, I'll put an end to your life, you jade!

sp.speaker: ACROPOLISTIS
sp.p: I shan't call you so. When you want to be my father, then be so; when you don't want, don't be my father.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: to PERIPHANES. What? Did you purchase her for that reason, because you supposed her to be your daughter? By what signs did you recognize her?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: By none.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Why did you suppose her to be our daughter?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: My servant Epidicus told me so.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: What if it had seemed to your servant otherwise? Prithee, could you not have known?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: How should I, who had never seen her after having once beheld her.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: Wretched creature, I'm quite undone! Begins to weep.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Don't weep, madam; go in-doors; be of good courage; I'll find her out.

sp.speaker: PHILIPPA
sp.p: An Attic citizen from Athens here purchased her Indeed, they said it was a young man who had bought her.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I will find her; hold your peace. Only do go in-doors, and keep an eye upon this CirceUpon this Circe: He calls her a Circe, because she has laid a spell upon him, as it were by enchantments, for which Circe was famous. Perhaps, too, he calls her a daughter of the Sun, from his not knowing who her father really is, when he has so recently supposed himself to be so., this daughter of the Sun. She goes into the house, followed by ACROPOLISTIS. All business laid aside, I'll give my attention to seeking for Epidicus. If I find him, I'll make this day become the final one for him. (Exit.)

div1.stage: Enter STRATIPPOCLES, from the house of CHÆRIBULUS.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: to himself. The BankerThe Banker: "Danista." This was from a Greek word, signifying a "banker," or "usurer." With an extraordinary degree of carelessness, Cotter takes it to be the proper name of a man, and calls him Danista. is inattentive to me, not to seek the money of me, or bring this woman who has been purchased out of the spoil. But see--here comes Epidicus How's this, that in gloominess his brow is wrinkled? at a distance.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p:
to himself. If Jupiter unto himself were to take the eleven GodsThe eleven Gods: He alludes to the eleven who, with Jupiter, made the "Dii majores." They are thus enumerated in two rugged lines of Ennius:
Juno, Vesta, Ceres, Diana, Minerva, Venus, Mars,
Mercurius Jovi, Neptunus, Vulcanus, Apollo. beside himself, even then, all of them would not be able to rescue Epidicus from torture. I've seen Periphanes buying the thongs; Apæcides was together with him; now, I do believe that these persons are in search of me. They have found it out; they know that they've been imposed upon.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: coming forward. What are you about, my ready occasion?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: That which a wretched fellow is about.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Why don't you prepare for me the necessaries for flight before I'm quite undone? For the two fleeced old gentlemen are hunting for me through the city; they are carrying in their hands handcuffs an inch and a half thick.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Be of good heart----

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Of course I will, whose freedom is so close at handIs so close at hand: "Quoi libertas in mundo sita est." This expression, no doubt, is intended to be used ironically by Epidicus..

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: I will preserve you.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I' faith, they'll do it better for me, if they catch me. But who's this young woman, this greyish old fellow, too, that's coming along? are seen at a distance.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: This is the Banker, and this is the woman whom I purchased out of the spoil.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What, is this she?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: It is she. Isn't she just like what I told you? Look at her.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Is it she?

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Survey her, Epidicus. Even from her nail to the top of her hair she is most lovely! Is she not? Do look at her! Observe her! You'll be looking at a picture beautifully painted.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p:
Judging from your words you are foretelling that my hide will be beautifully painted; me, whom Apelles and ZeuxisApelles and Zeuxis: See the Notes to the Pœnulus, l. 1289. He alludes to Periphanes and Apæcides, who will cause his back to be marked with elm-twigs., the pair of them, will be painting with elm-tree pigments.
Enter the BANKER and TELESTIS.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: to the BANKER. Immortal Gods! I'm surprised at your slowness. The man that's spoken of in the proverb with swollen feet, would have got here sooner than you have arrived for me.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: pointing to TELESTIS. I' faith, 'twas she delayed me.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: If indeed you delayed for her sake, because she wished it, you have come too quickly.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: Well, well, dispatch with me and count out the money, that I mayn't be detaining my friends.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: It has been counted out.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: giving him a bag. Take this bag; put it into it.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: You come discreetly provided! Wait till I bring out the money to you.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: Make haste.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: It's at home. Goes into the house of CHÆRIBULUS.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: looking steadily at TELESTIS. Have I the use of my eyes quite unimpaired, or is it otherwise? Do I not behold in you, Telestis, the daughter of Periphanes, born at Thebes of your mother Philippa, and conceived at Epidaurus?

sp.speaker: TELESTIS
sp.p: What person are you who are making mention of the name of my parents and my own?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Don't you know me?

sp.speaker: TELESTIS
