sp.p: Not, indeed, so far as recurs to my mind just now.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Don't you remember my bringing you a crescent upon your birthday, and a little gold ring for your finger? STRATIPPOCLES returns with the money.

sp.speaker: TELESTIS
sp.p: I remember it. What, are you that person?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I am, and pointing to STRATIPPOCLES, at a distance he there is your brother by another mother and the same father.

sp.speaker: TELESTIS
sp.p: in agitation. What of my father? Is he alive?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Be of calm and composed feelings; hold your peace.

sp.speaker: TELESTIS
sp.p: The Gods will that from being lost I should be saved, if you speak the truth.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I have no occasion to be telling untruths to you.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: to the BANKER. Take this money, Banker; here are forty minæ. If any piece shall be doubtful I'll change it. Gives him the money.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: You do well. Kindly farewell. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: to TELESTIS. Now then you are my own----

sp.speaker: TELESTIS
sp.p: Why yes--sister, i' faith, that you may know it as well. Greetings to you, brother.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: to EPIDICUS. Is this woman in her senses?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: In her senses, if she calls you her brother.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: How's this? Have I just now become her brother while going in-doors and coming out?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What good fortune there is, do you in silence keep your peace thereon and rejoice.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Sister, you have both lost and found me!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Simpleton, hold your tongue! Through my endeavours, there's ready for you at home, in fact, a Music-girl for you to make love to; I too, through my endeavours, have restored your sister to liberty.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Epidicus, I confess----

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Be off into the house, and order the water to be made warmThe water to be made warm: A bath was usually taken by the middle and upper classes immediately on arriving from a journey. for her. The rest I'll let you know afterwards, when there's leisure.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: Follow me this way, sister.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I'll bid ThesprioI'll bid Thesprio: Thesprio only appears once, and that at the beginning of the Play. This is certainly a prevalent fault with Plautus, who does not make the most of his characters. Artotrogus, the Parasite, in the Miles Gloriosus, is lost to us after the First Scene. Sceparnio only appears in the First and Second Acts of the Rudens, and the honest Grumio is lost sight of after the First Act of the Mostellaria. It is not a sufficient excuse to plead that Artotrogus and Thesprio are what were called "personæ protaticæ," characters whose business it is to introduce the plot, and do no more; even though this example is followed by Terence, who similarly introduces Sosia in the Andria, Davus in the Phormio, and Philotis in the Hecyra. come across to you. But remember, if the old gentlemen are at all savage, you, with your sister, to run and help me.

sp.speaker: STRATIPPOCLES
sp.p: That will be easy. He and TELESTIS go into the house of PERIPHANES.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: going to the door of the house of CHÆRIBULUS. Thesprio, come this way through the garden. Come to my rescue at home! The matter's of importance! To himself. I care much less for the old fellows than I did just now. I'll return in-doors, that the strangers may be attended to on their arrival. I'll tell these same things that I know, in-doors to Stratippocles. I shall not take to flight; I'm determined to be there at home, and he shan't throw it in my teeth that he has been provoked by my running awayBy my running away: "Pedibus." Literally, "by my feet.". I'll away in-doors; I've been talking too long. (Goes into the house of PERIPHANES.)

div1.stage: Enter PERIPHANES and APÆCIDES, with thongs in their hands.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Hasn't this fellow quite made a laughing-stock of us two decrepit old peopleDecrepit old people: "Decrepitos." From the verb "decrepo," "to crackle," or "make a sputtering," as a candle does when going out, or the wick of a lamp when the oil fails.?

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Why yes, I' faith, you've really kept me plagued in a shocking fashion.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Now do hold your tongue. Only let me catch the fellow!

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: I'll tell you now, that you may know it. It's best for you to seek another companion; so much, while I've been following you, has the congested blood, from weariness, come down into the knees of poor me.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: After how many fashions has this fellow made sport of me and you to-day! besides, how he has disembowelled my silver resources for me!

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Away with him from me; for surely he's the son of Vulcan in his wrath: wherever he touches, he sets all on fire; if you stand by him, he scorches you with his heat. unperceived, from the house.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: to himself. More than the twelve Gods, the immortal Gods as many as are in the heavens, are now assistants in my rescue, and are fighting on my side. As to whatever I have offended in, I have aid and assistance at homeAssistance at home: He alludes to Stratippocles, Telestis, Philippa, Thesprio, and probably Chæribulus, who are all ready to take his part; and, indeed, have good reason to do so, from the opportune discovery which he has just made.. All my enemies I quite spurn by the heelsSpurn by the heels: *)apolaktizw/. It has been more than once remarked that the use of Greek words was much affected by the Romans, in the same way that we make use of French phrases..

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: looking about. Where in the world shall I look for him?

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: So long as you look for him without me, you may look for him even in the middle of the sea, as far as I'm concerned.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: coming forward, and addressing PERIPHANES Why are you looking for me? Why are you taking this trouble? Why are you worrying him? Pointing to APÆCIDES. See, here I am. Have I run away from you? Have I betaken myself from the house? Have I hid myself from your sight? I don't entreat you either. Do you wish to bind me? Look then, I present my hands. Holding out his hands. You have got thongs; I saw you purchase them. Why do you delay now? Do bind me!

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: It's all overIt's all over: "Ilicet." Literally, "you may begone;" the word used when judicial proceedings had terminated.. He gives bail to me of his own accord for his appearance.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Why don't you bind me?

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: A wicked slave, upon my faith!

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Really, Apæcides, I don't want you to intercede for me.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: You easily obtain your wish, Epidicus.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: to PERIPHANES. Are you going to do anything?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What, at your pleasure?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Troth, at my own, indeed, and not at yours, are these hands to be bound by you to-day.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: But I don't choose; I shan't bind them.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: to PERIPHANES. He's preparing to throw a dragnet over you; he's framing some plan, I know not what.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: You are causing delay to yourself, while I stand unbound; bind them, I tell you, bind them together.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: But I choose rather to question you unbound.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: But you shall know nothing.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: turning to APÆCIDES. What am I to do?

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: What are you to do? Let him be complied with.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: You are a worthy person, Apæcides.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Hold out your hands then.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: holding out his hands. They don't at all object; bind them fast together too. Don't be afraid. PERIPHANES binds his hands. I'm submissive. When the job is done, then pronounce your judgmentPronounce your judgment: "Arbitraminor" seems a better reading than "arbitramino.".

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: There, that is good.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Now then, to the point, with your enquiries of me; ask me what you please.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: In the first place, with what assurance did you presume to say that she who was bought the day before yesterday was my daughter?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I chose to; on that assurance.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Do you say so? You chose to?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I do say so. Even lay me a wager that she is not the daughter----

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: A woman whom the mother declares she doesn't know?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Then, if she isn't the daughter of her mother, make me a bet about it, my didrachm to your talentMy didrachm to your talent: The moderate odds of three thousand to one..

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Why, that's a mere catch. But who is this woman?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: The mistress of your son, that you may know the whole matter.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Did I not give you the thirty minæ for my daughter?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I confess that they were given, and that with that money I purchased this Music-girl, your son's mistress, instead of your daughter. As to those thirty minæ, in fact, I imposed upon you.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: For what reason did you play a trick upon me about that hired Music-girl?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I' faith, I really did do it, and I think it was rightly done.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: In the last place, what has been done with the silver I gave you?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I'll tell you; I gave it to a person neither bad nor yet goodNor yet good: "Indigno" is read here in some editions for "benigno," and is, perhaps, a better reading; though Epidicus may, possibly, as Post suggests, intend to allude satirically to the undecided and versatile character of Stratippocles.--your son Stratippocles.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Why did you dare to give it him?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Because it pleased me.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: stamping. Plague on it! what insolence is this?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Am I to be bawled at just as if I were a slave?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: ironically. As you are a free man, I rejoice.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I have deserved to become so.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: You--deserved?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Go look in-doors; I'll let you know that this is the truth.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: The thing itself will tell you so at once. Only do go in-doors.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Aye, aye! this is not without its meaning. Do you keep an eye on him, Apæcides. Goes into his house.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: What's the meaning of this, Epidicus?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I' faith, it's with the greatest injustice that I'm standing here bound, through whose aid his daughter has been discovered to-day.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: Do you say that you have found his daughter?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I have found her, and she is at home. But how hard it is, when, for services done, you reap a harvest of evil.

sp.speaker: APAECIDES
sp.p: What, her whom this day we've both been weary with seeking throughout the city?

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p:
I'm weary with finding, you weary with seeking.
from the house.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: at the door, to those within. Why do you entreat me thus earnestly in his behalf? For I find that he does deserve that I should be pleased to act according to his deserts. To EPIDICUS. Hold out your hands, you, that I may unbind them.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Don't you touch them.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: But do you present them to me.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: I don't choose.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: You don't do right.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Upon my faith, I'll never allow myself to be unbound this day, unless you give me satisfaction.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: You ask what's very fair and very just. Shoes, a tunic, and a cloak I'll give you.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: What next, after that?

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: Your freedom.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: But after that? There's need for a new-made freed-man to pick a bitTo pick a bit: "Pappet." "Pappo" properly signifies "to eat pap," as children do..

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: It shall be given; I'll find you food.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: On my word, never this day shall you release me, unless you beg my pardon.

sp.speaker: PERIPHIANES
sp.p: I do entreat you, Epidicus, to forgive me, if unawares in fault I've done anything wrong. But by way of return for this matter, be a free man.

sp.speaker: EPIDICUS
sp.p: Against my inclination do I grant you this pardon, but I'm compelled by necessity. Unbind them then, if you choose. He holds out his hands, which are unbound by PERIPHANES, and they go into his house. coming forward.
This is that man who by his rogueryBy his roguery: -- "Malitia," "artfulness." "trickery." has gained his freedom. Clap your hands, and fare you well! Stretch your loins, and rise from your seats.
